docs.lead_paragraph: For the second time in two months, The Journal of the American Medical Association says it was misled by researchers who failed to disclose financial ties to drug companies. The journal is tightening its policies for researchers as a result.

headline.main: Medical Journal Says It Was Again Misled

docs.abstract: Journal of American Medical Association reports that most of 13 authors of article it published on use of antidepressants during pregnancy have financial ties to drug companies, including antidepressant makers, but that just two disclosed their ties when study was published in February; report found that pregnant women who stop takng antidepressants risk slipping back into depression (M)
docs.snippet: For the second time in two months, The Journal of the American Medical Association says it was misled by researchers who failed to disclose financial ties to drug companies.     The journal is tightening its policies for researchers as a result.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: Readers respond to articles in Science Times with thoughts on physics, the effect of genes on health, decisions about prostate cancer treatment and more.

docs.lead_paragraph: Rich donors can be a fickle but essential source of aid for medical research.

headline.sub: Rich Donors Can Be a Fickle but Essential Source of Aid for Medical Research ;

docs.snippet: Rich donors can be a fickle but essential source of aid for medical research.

docs.lead_paragraph: When Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, pulled back recently from a plan to donate $115 million to Harvard, Richard L. Sprott was reminded again of the tenuous nature of his livelihood. Mr. Sprott is the executive director of the Ellison Medical Foundation, a philanthropy that has received $175 million from Mr. Ellison mostly to aid research on the science of aging. Although the Harvard situation was unrelated to the foundation -- Mr. Ellison reportedly changed his mind about donating after the resignation in February of Lawrence H. Summers, the president of Harvard, amid a storm of controversy -- the events reinforced for Mr. Sprott his awareness that his organization also depended on a single billionaire.
docs.abstract: Wealthy individuals are growing force behind medical research through philanthropies and causes they support; critics express concern about potential overreliance on generosity and its impact on health care; hold that important medical and social decisions are in hands of small number of donors and government may stop funding for programs if philanthropies tackle problems; agree that private funding allows for more risk and innovative solutions; photos (M)
